sentences: Lavell William Crump  (born April 11, 1974), better known by his stage name David Banner, is an American rapper, record producer, and actor.
section: N/A

sentences: Born in Brookhaven, Mississippi, Banner's family moved to Jackson, Mississippi where he was raised.
section: N/A

sentences: Banner graduated from Southern University and pursued a masters of education at the University of Maryland Eastern Shore.
section: N/A

sentences: He started his music career as a member of the rap duo, Crooked Lettaz, before going solo in 2000 with the release titled Them Firewater Boyz, Vol. 1.
section: N/A

sentences: In 2003, Banner signed to Universal Records, where he released four albums: Mississippi: The Album (2003), MTA2: Baptized in Dirty Water (2003), Certified (2005), and The Greatest Story Ever Told (2008).
section: N/A

== Early life ==

sentences: Early life ==
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Lavell William Crump was born in Brookhaven and raised in Jackson, Mississippi, the elder son of Zeno Crump, Jr., Jackson district fire chief, and Carolyn Crump.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: He graduated from Provine High School in Jackson in 1992 and then attended Southern University in Baton Rouge, Louisiana, his mother's alma mater.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: At Southern University, Crump served as president of the Student Government Association and received a bachelor's degree in business.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: He later attended the University of Maryland Eastern Shore to pursue a master's degree in education but later left the program to pursue his music career full-time.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: After assessing various offers, Banner and manager, Scott Johnson, decided to sign with Universal Records subsidiary, SRC Records, which was founded by Steve Rifkind who had previous success as CEO of the heavyweight hip-hop label, Loud Records.
section: == Music career == | === 2003–06: Mississippi: The Album, MTA2: Baptized in Dirty Water and Certified ===

sentences: In 2003, Banner produced T.I.'s single, "Rubberband Man", which reached #30 on the Hot 100, #15 on the R&B chart, and #11 on the Rap chart.
section: == Music career == | === 2003–06: Mississippi: The Album, MTA2: Baptized in Dirty Water and Certified ===

sentences: In 2003, Banner released his first major label album, Mississippi: The Album.

sentences: Mississippi included the hit single, "Like a Pimp", featuring Lil Flip.

== Humanitarian and political work ==

sentences: Humanitarian and political work ==
section: == Humanitarian and political work ==

sentences: In November 2006, Banner was awarded a Visionary Award by the National Black Caucus of State Legislators in Jackson, Mississippi  in recognition of his humanitarian work in response to Hurricane Katrina.
section: == Humanitarian and political work ==

sentences: On September 25, 2007, Banner testified before Congress at a hearing about racism and misogyny in hip hop music titled From Imus to Industry: The Business of Stereotypes and Degrading Images.
section: == Humanitarian and political work ==

sentences: He defended his use of offensive language and argued: "Change the situation in my neighborhood and maybe I'll get better."
section: == Humanitarian and political work ==

sentences: In his opening statement, Banner stated: "I can admit there are some problems in hip hop
section: == Humanitarian and political work ==

sentences: but it is only a reflection of what's taking place in our society.
section: == Humanitarian and political work ==

sentences: Hip hop is sick because America is sick."
section: == Humanitarian and political work ==
